Award.AwardTitle: Air-Sea Exchange and Boundary Layer Chemistry of Mercury over the Open Ocean
Award.AbstractNarration:
The atmosphere is the most important source of mercury (Hg) to the marine environment and air-sea exchange is a major pathway for both the addition and removal of Hg from the atmosphere. Preliminary data suggests that the cycling of Hg at the air-sea interface is a complex process involving abiotic (photochemical) oxidation of elemental Hg (Hg0) and reduction of ionic Hg (HgII) in surface waters, as well as oxidation of Hg0 in the atmospheric boundary layer.

A scientist from the University of Connecticut plans to assess the importance of these processes by determining the variation in the speciation of Hg and other ancillary measurements in atmospheric and surface water samples recovered from one site in the North Atlantic near Bermuda and another from Cape Point, South Africa. The resulting data set would be used to test the following three hypotheses: (1) photochemical oxidation of Hg0 in surface seawater occurs but the overall net reaction is HgII reduction; (2) organic matter is the primary dissolved constituent influencing the rate of HgII reductions in surface seawater; and (3) oxidation of Hg0 in the marine boundary layer and subsequent dry deposition of HgII compounds is substantial and rivals that of wet deposition. Controlled incubation experiments would also be carried out to determine redox transformations in surface waters. Lastly, the data from the project would be used to constrain and improve ocean and global Hg models, as well as incorporate their results into model simulations using the Harvard University GEOS-Chem modeling framework.

As regards broader impacts, this study would further our understanding of the Hg cycle. This study would allow U.S. scientists to interact with their counterparts in South Africa and would continue to build international collaborations with South African institutions. One postdoc, one graduate student, and one undergraduate student would be supported and trained as part of this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of the project was investigating the exchange of mercury, a potentially toxic element, whose concentrations in the biosphere has been increased as a result of human activities (e.g. mining, coal burning, incineration), between the ocean and the atmosphere. Most of the mercury entering the ocean comes from the atmosphere through precipitation and deposition of gaeous and particulate forms of mercury. Most of this mercury is ionic. In the ocean these inputs of ionic mercury are converted either to the more toxic and bioaccumulative methylmercury or are removed from the ocean through its conversion to elemental mercury, which is a volatile gas that can evade to the atmosphere, or through other processes which are less important. As mercury can exist as a dissolved gas in seawater it is very different from most other heavy metals. As elemental mercury can build up to supersaturated concentrations in the surface ocean, it can degass back to the atmosphere. Therefore, the extent and rate of conversion to elemental mercury removes mercury from the ocean that could be otherwise transported to regions where it is converted to methylmercury. Thus, the extent of evasion mitigates the impact of human releases of mercury on ocean fish concentrations.

The study was designed to examine the rates of addition of mercury to the ocean from the atmosphere and the rates at which this added mercury was converted to elemental mercury and returned to the atmosphere. The mechanisms whereby the ionic mercury is converted to elemental mercury in the ocean are both photochemical (i.e. the reactions are driven by solar energy) or microbial. In addition, it is possible for the elemental mercury to be converted back to ionic mercury by photochemical processes. All these processes and the factors affecting their rate of reaction were investigated.  The main research was conducted on five research expeditions in the vicinity of Bermuda in the North Atlantic Ocean as well as during studies at a atmospheric station on Bermuda, and through laboratory studies. The results of the study have allowed us to develop a better model of the processes involved in mercury exchange at the sea/air interface and has allowed us to scale the results of the studies in the North Atlantic globally. A number of papers and presentations have resulted from this study and the work has been part of the PhD research of one graduate student, while other graduate and undergraduate students were also involved in the project. The studies has also allowed the research development of two post-doctoral investigators. The majority of these students and post-docs have been women and/or minorities. The results of this work have allowed the development of global models that are more accurately predicting the impact of human activity on mercury in the biosphere and in marine fish and shellfish.
